name: Box Breathing & Structured Breathwork
description: Structured breathing patterns that calm the nervous system, reduce anxiety, and improve focus. Used by Navy SEALs, athletes, and meditation practitioners.

exercises.name: Box Breathing (4-4-4-4)
exercises.description: Equal parts breathing: inhale, hold, exhale, hold - all for 4 counts
exercises.instructions: Sit comfortably. Inhale through nose for 4 counts, hold for 4, exhale through mouth for 4, hold empty for 4. Repeat for 5 minutes.
benefits: Lowers heart rate and blood pressure
exercises.bestUsedFor: Before stressful situations, after intense workouts, when feeling anxious, before bed
exercises.scienceBacked: Activates parasympathetic nervous system, proven effective for stress reduction

exercises.name: Extended Box Breathing (5-5-5-5)
exercises.instructions: Inhale 5 counts, hold 5, exhale 5, hold 5. Repeat for 8 minutes. Stay relaxed throughout - don't force.

modifications.easier: Return to 4-4-4-4 if 5 feels too long

conditions.anxiety: If this increases anxiety, try shorter counts or skip the holds

exercises.bestUsedFor: Deep relaxation, meditation preparation, sleep onset

exercises.name: Tactical Breathing (4-4-4)
exercises.description: Navy SEAL breathing technique - no bottom hold
exercises.instructions: Inhale 4 counts, hold 4, exhale 4. NO hold at bottom - immediately begin next inhale. Repeat for 5 minutes.
exercises.bestUsedFor: Pre-performance anxiety, acute stress, when you need to stay alert but calm
exercises.usedBy: Navy SEALs, first responders, athletes before competition

exercises.name: Rectangle Breathing (4-2-6-2)
exercises.description: Uneven pattern with extended exhale for deeper calm
exercises.instructions: Inhale 4, hold 2, exhale 6, hold 2. Repeat for 8 minutes. Focus on slow, controlled exhale.
benefits: Extended exhale activates vagus nerve strongly
Reduces heart rate more than equal breathing
exercises.bestUsedFor: Evening relaxation, pre-sleep, deep stress relief
exercises.scienceBacked: Longer exhale stimulates vagus nerve, proven anxiety reducer

exercises.name: Energizing Breath Pattern (4-0-4-0)
exercises.description: No holds, continuous breathing for energy and alertness
exercises.instructions: Sit upright. Continuous breathing: inhale 4, exhale 4, no pauses. Slightly faster than resting pace. 5 minutes total.

modifications.harder: Faster: 3-0-3-0 pattern (be careful not to hyperventilate)

exercises.bestUsedFor: Morning wake-up, mid-afternoon energy dip, before focus work
exercises.caution: Don't go too fast - should never feel lightheaded or tingly

exercises.name: Coherent Breathing (5-5)
exercises.description: 5 seconds in, 5 seconds out - optimal heart rate variability
exercises.instructions: Inhale gently for 5 seconds, exhale gently for 5 seconds. No holds. Aim for about 6 breaths per minute. Continue for 10 minutes.

modifications.harder: Extend to 20 minutes for deep practice

exercises.bestUsedFor: Daily practice, building stress resilience, HRV training
exercises.scienceBacked: Research shows 6 breaths/min optimizes HRV and nervous system balance
